citations.narrative:
On July 7th, 2023, a female ring-tailed lemur bit a child on the finger when he reached into the lemur's enclosure. There is
a climbing structure adjacent to the lemur enclosure with additional fencing and solid barriers to prevent access to the
lemurs. During public viewing, the child was able to reach over the barrier and moved an unsecured panel, which allowed
direct contact with the lemur, who then bit the child. The bite broke skin but did not require medical attention. Unprotected
public contact with animals can cause injury to the public or the animals. Correct before next public exhibition, no later
than 7/14/23, by ensuring sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and general viewing public so as to
assure the safety of animals and the public.

Three cats are housed in a 2 sheltered enclosures on an unsealed wooden floor that is not impervious to moisture. In both
enclosures, there are several large areas of darkened wood floor that has absorbed moisture. Floors and surfaces that
absorb water, urine, and other fluids, can not be effectively cleaned and sanitized, which can damage structural integrity
and harbor disease. Correct by 8/11/23 by ensuring all sheltered surfaces in contact with animals are impervious to
moisture.

A female arctic fox is housed in an enclosure with sharp, broken wires protruding up from the floor. The enclosure has a
wire floor covered by mulch. The corners of the enclosure have been dug up, exposing the wire floor. In the front corner,
by the gate, multiple wires are broken and protruding upwards. Sharp points can cause injury. Correct by 7/25/23 by
ensuring the enclosure is structurally sound and maintained in order to contain and protect the animals from injury.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Kem Singletary, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(c)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
On July 7th, 2023, a female ring-tailed lemur bit a child on the finger when he reached into the lemur's enclosure. There is 
a climbing structure adjacent to the lemur enclosure with additional fencing and solid barriers to prevent access to the 
lemurs. During public viewing, the child was able to reach over the barrier and moved an unsecured panel, which allowed 
direct contact with the lemur, who then bit the child. The bite broke skin but did not require medical attention. Unprotected 
public contact with animals can cause injury to the public or the animals. Correct before next public exhibition, no later 
than 7/14/23, by ensuring sufficient distance and/or barriers between the animal and general viewing public so as to 
assure the safety of animals and the public. 
3.3(e)(1)(i) 
   
Sheltered housing facilities. 
Three cats are housed in a 2 sheltered enclosures on an unsealed wooden floor that is not impervious to moisture. In both 
enclosures, there are several large areas of darkened wood floor that has absorbed moisture. Floors and surfaces that 
absorb water, urine, and other fluids, can not be effectively cleaned and sanitized, which can damage structural integrity 
and harbor disease. Correct by 8/11/23 by ensuring all sheltered surfaces in contact with animals are impervious to 
moisture. 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
A female arctic fox is housed in an enclosure with sharp, broken wires protruding up from the floor. The enclosure has a 
wire floor covered by mulch. The corners of the enclosure have been dug up, exposing the wire floor. In the front corner, 
by the gate, multiple wires are broken and protruding upwards. Sharp points can cause injury. Correct by 7/25/23 by 
ensuring the enclosure is structurally sound and maintained in order to contain and protect the animals from injury. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.

Additional Inspectors: 
Kem Singletary, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
